title: 114_s3344
content: The Act may be cited as the "Innovation for Tomorrow's Workforce Act" and includes provisions for an Innovation Fund. Section 114 of the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to include a grant program for innovative strategies to improve career and technical education and align workforce skills with labor market needs. Grants may be awarded for evidence-based innovations, including pay for success initiatives to enhance student outcomes. The grant program under the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 aims to improve career and technical education outcomes, teacher effectiveness, student transitions to postsecondary education or employment, and work-based learning incorporation. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 aims to enhance career and technical education by increasing technology use, integrating academic and apprenticeship content, developing innovative delivery models, and collaborating with industry for course design and implementation. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 aims to design and implement courses aligned to labor market needs in new fields, integrate STEM fields with career education, and support innovative approaches in high school education. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 aims to improve career and technical education outcomes in nontraditional fields, support programs to address employer needs and workforce shortages in education sectors. The Carl D. Perkins Act of 2006 focuses on enhancing career and technical education, including workforce innovations and rigorous evaluations. Eligible entities must provide matching funds of at least 25% from public or private sources to receive a grant, with the option for the Secretary to waive this requirement in certain cases. To receive a grant under the Carl D. Perkins Act of 2006, eligible entities must submit an application identifying the responsible agency, ensure matching funds are obtained, and demonstrate exceptional circumstances for a waiver of the matching fund requirement. The eligible entity must describe how grant funds will benefit students, especially special populations, and how the program will be coordinated with other activities. Priority is given to entities serving low-income families, and geographic diversity is considered in grant awards. The Secretary shall award at least 25 percent of funds to eligible entities for career and technical education activities serving specific urban-centric districts, institutions of higher education, consortia of local educational agencies or institutions, and partnerships. The grant funds awarded to eligible entities must be used in accordance with specific guidelines, and each recipient must undergo evaluation. Eligible entities can form partnerships with educational service agencies, nonprofit organizations, local educational agencies, institutions of higher education, or State educational agencies to receive the grant. The grant recipients must undergo independent evaluation and submit an annual report detailing fund usage and performance indicators. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, including special populations and career and technical education programs. The curr_chunk provides a quantitative analysis of the project's effectiveness under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. It defines an eligible entity as a consortium including a local educational agency, an educational service agency, or an area career and technical education school. The curr_chunk lists eligible entities for funding under the Act, including postsecondary educational institutions, State educational agencies, the Bureau of Indian Education, State apprenticeship agencies, and employers. The consortium, led by an entity described in the previous paragraph, is eligible for funding under the Act. The term 'pay for success initiative' is defined in another education act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for funding. The Act authorizes necessary appropriations for the consortium led by a specified entity. Subsection (e) is amended to exclude subsection (d)(6) from the section. SEC. 3. OPEN EDUCATION RESOURCES. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 regarding the availability of instructional content, including the use of open educational resources at both state and local levels. The text chunk emphasizes the goal of making instructional content widely available, potentially utilizing open educational resources. The text chunk introduces support for pay-for-success initiatives in education under the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006. It also mentions the inclusion of work-based learning opportunities and apprenticeships. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to include support for work-based learning opportunities and apprenticeships at both the state and local levels. This includes employer-led training leading to recognized credentials.
